reviewText:
[8/10] - Just Add Water's console-to-PC port reawakens the 2005 Xbox release with better visuals, audio, and stability on the PC... for the most part.

Stranger's Wrath is a fairly straight-forward action/adventure strategy game that introduces a unique gameplay mechanic where your ammo consists of tiny creatures each with a distinct ability to distract, devour, and destroy your enemies. The game allows you to seamlessly alternate between a third-person view for ease of mobility, and a first-person view for shooting the critters at foes and obstacles. Every level brings on a diverse challenge that can be approached differently each time and delivers enjoyable boss fights that can be demanding enough to make you rethink your strategy. The story is interesting and comical and introduces twists and turns that completely change the atmosphere of the game without going too far out into the bizzare. It IS an oddworld, after all.

On the downside, Stranger's Wrath suffers from some aggravating glitches and performance flaws that remind you of the horrors that follow game ports. Issues such as loading errors, frame-rate drop, achievements not unlocking, textures missing, and incorrect subtitles are littered throughout the game. Stranger, the protagonist, has poor voice acting and every creature of the same species has the SAME voice-over which easily breaks the personality of the subservient characters, and diminishes the quality of the game itself. There is not much progression other than unlocking unique ammo and some minor upgrades. Most of the more interesting unlocks are not revealed until much later in the game, but at that point it really starts get a lot more exciting and fun.

Overall, I found the game to be satisfying to the end. Playing on hard and attempting to capture the enemies alive rather than dead makes the game challenging, but not at all frustrating. With a little patience to tolerate the technical flaws, Stranger's Wrath can be a very enjoyable experience. Out of all the games included in the Oddbox anthology, this one is by far the best out of the four.

reviewText:
Stranger's Wrath is a really mindblowing and innovating game. Being 11 years old it still hold gameplay and mechanics, that are solid to this day. This game was so far ahead of its time.
As a player you will get a huge amount of content, a huge variety of ammo and loads of different ways to complete the levels. You play as a bounty hunter and you are equipped with a crossbow, that uses ammo in forms of critters that you hunt. That means you shoot down bad guys with spiders, fuzzles or even bats! You choose yourself how you will deploy this ammo, as they all has their own purpose; wrap them in web, deploy as a living mine or shoot a living skunk that makes the enemy throw up. The games really leaves you with a whole lot of choices. You even get to decide if you want to kill the bandits, or catch them alive for a bigger bounty.

The enviroment is great and I don't usually like deserts, but I found this one fun and exciting. It was in no way empty. As the game progress you are taken from the desert to the forest, temples, jungles and even more places, so the scenery constantly changes, with a lot of lore and detail, which keeps the player constantly occupied. Together with a lot of content and challenges, this really wraps up a good experience. I found to have ZERO problems playing this game and had no crashes at all. I was even surprised of how well and good the control and camera were. I felt it was made for PC. I did experience only getting the 'Easy'-achievement, even though I finished it on 'Hard'. All other achivements worked and I am sure this is not a common thing. The Achievements are fun and interesting to complete. They are realistic, but hard, so I would recommend doing them. Fun and a good challenge.

For people who played the previous Oddworld games: You are in for a treat! Even though Abe and Munch is far away and not present, the keen eye will spot references and items from RuptureFarms and such. Even some of the wildlife that lives in these parts, also exists in Abe's part of Oddworld. The two are woven good together and the old-school fan will surely feel some nostalgia when noticing those things. The story is as always extremely good and really reflects on things from our real world. The game has a great message that is delivered with an awesome storytelling and interesting gameplay.

This game's mechanics and content easily beats todays big games. They have always been very creative, the guys behind these games. The game is also very re-playable, which games rarely are.

9.5/10
*Would have been 10 if the Hard-achievement had worked for me.

Bounty huntin' platformer that's mostly a first-person shooter where your only real weapon is a crossbow that only fires living ammunition. There's a third person perspective but I only really found myself using that perspective for travelling and checking from behind cover. Each town you go to has a bounty you can take to earn moolah which can be used to get yourself some upgrades or other possibly useful items. Each bounty or boss aren't entirely unique to one another though there can be an enjoyment had in each of 'em. After a town's been exhausted of its bounties you move on to travel to another town with bounties you can accept.
Finding your next objective for the most part isn't always obvious or pointed out either. Directions are generally figured out by talking to townsfolk.
Each type of ammo is used strategically whether you're planning on being sneaky or just straight up running in firing hornets at full auto, taking in baddies dead or alive, it's up to you.
The stealth isn't very in-depth so learning from and manipulating it to your advantage shouldn't be very difficult especially since the AI can be as dumb as the characters they portray.

Have you ever wanted to step into the boots of a stone cold bounty hunter bringing in criminals and making piles of cash? Then this might just be the game for you. Oh and it takes place on an alien world where everything is crazy too.

This game is great fun; it starts off a little slow but once it gets rolling you will have a hard time putting it down. Set in oddworld you know it’s going to be crazy. Every mission and town you go through has its own little narrative and everything seems to be an adventure all culminating in an epic tale of vengeance and surgery…..yes.

I loved the bounty system, it’s one of my favourite things in any game and in this one it’s great. Take people in alive and get paid more money, even bosses can be brought in alive. It just adds another layer of challenge to the title. Something about collecting them all drove me to obsession.

The story and world are obviously fantastic, neither are expanded on greatly but they add a sense that there is a lot more going on in the world around you and you are just carving your way through a very tiny part of it. The character you portray is a man of few words and that just adds to the mystery of who he is and what he wants.

Now we talk about the weapon, you only get one but with the HUGE amount of ammo (living critters you catch and shoot at bad guys) you will not be disappointed. It is one of the most unique weapons I have used in any game and with all the upgrades you can get throughout the adventure it always seems new and fresh.

The combat is fast paced and seamlessly switches from third person fighter to first person shooter. Both have their place and neither feels tacked on. There are tons of environments to explore and fight in and so many enemies to kill or capture each with their own personality. And the difficulty could be pretty brutal in places.

I would recommend this game if you have a few hours to spare and want to get taken into a world that’s more crazy and odd than most. The npc’s are huge chickens for gods sake. On sale you have to have this.

Out of alle the Oddworld games, Strangers Wrath was always the one I overlooked. Didn't have an original Xbox back in the day and when they released the HD version it was riddled with hella bugs. But now I finally gave it a whirl!

Strangers Wrath is a unique blend of 3rd person platforming and 1st person shooting. Most of the game evolves around bountyhunting outlaws, those little bossfights give you room for lethal and even nonlethal approaches which you'll want to do to earn more moolah. True to the universe, the world is hella ...odd, one cool aspect is that the ammo for your gun are living critters which you need to hunt to restock constantly. There are almost a dozen different critters to use to give room for the own preferred playstyle. The game never got boring, allthough the first half until a certain reveal might overstay its welcome a little bit. But what happens leading up to the games end is ridiculous and definitely worth seeing.

As expected and reported numerously, Strangers Wrath HD comes with some hefty technical shortcomings. This is as barebones as a PC port can get, I had to fiddle with graphical settings for almost half an hour until I had no strange FPS problems or weird bugs like my character not being able to move forward (Tip: turn vsync on!). There is controller support but it's not good, the game lets you rebind all the buttons but prompts show up as JOY1, JOY2. Fortunately the keyboard+mouse controls are totally fine and give benefits when aiming in first person mode.

Strangers Wrath is a really really cool game which combines 3rd person and 1st person action unlike anything I've seen before and ultimately -considering it's over 10 years old at this point- left me very impressed. The world and its characters are exactly what you expect when Lorne Lanning gets to work his magic. Speaking of which, he really should make a new game!

reviewText:
After the apparent shortcomings of Munch's Oddesy, the Oddworld crew wisely decided to invest in creating a new hero for the franchise, something that was fresh and fit well into the 3D scene. Abe never felt like he fit in with a 3D platformer and with Munch being tied to Abe... Stranger was a good alternative to explore Oddworld in a 3D envrioment. It was a risk; and one that payed off in aces. It introduces gameplay mechanics and an immersive story that devs struggle, more often then not, fail in leaps to pull off today.

You hunt your bounties with live ammo and it's up to you to decide how to do it, or If you want to chuck the bounties in the slammer or get rid of them for good.

The more useful ammo, such as bolimites, fuzzles and chipmunks come up quite freqnetly and is often high in the ammo department, while some of the more damaging creatures are rare. The game does push you towards getting the enemies alive through the abundant ammo of that nature and higher payout, but it's also often a lot harder for that route. Which makes two distinct playstyles and either way, you need to get creative.

Bosses are often tough, and require good knowledge of your ammo in order to capture them alive.

With the game itself out of the way, lets talk about the port.

Many people have seen issues with performance, on my 7970, it runs well and I've never seen a problem. BUT. you need to check if it will run. there are some demanding features, such as grass, which will have in game implications if you're forced to disable them as you might not have any idea you can hide over there for example.

The achievements in this game are also borked. they will not save progress if you quit. that is to say, you will bounty 250 bad guys and you won't get rewarded for it unless you either play the game for long enough to get it; or you save and farm quick loads so you can bounty one or two idiots over and over.

reviewText:
Not a review of the port itself. I was very fortunate in being able to have a rig which supported a smooth port experience. However, there were still occasional visual glitches and the game crashed every time after I died during the last few segments of the game. So even at its best performance the game runs only adequately.

I wish I could say I enjoyed this game more. The most creative aspect of the game is using the creature ammos to capture or kill enemies. This dead or alive bounty hunting mechanic is the core of the gameplay, but it barely gets developed upon after its introduced, and what's worse is that they ditch several mechanics after the halfway point of the game. The game can be played in the 3rd as well 1st person perspective, but all the 3rd person perspective is for is very basic 3rd person platforming and combat, as well as traversing the levels faster. The game has a currency which the plot informs the player is very important, motivating the player to capture more enemies than they kill. This makes for interesting gameplay, as it takes longer and is more risky to capture enemies alive than it is to kill them, but alive enemies pay out more. The earlier levels are also built around a combination of stealth and cover, which combined with the creative crossbow tools, gives the play options in how to complete a level. There are also upgrades and ammo to buy, giving you more to do with your money.

Without spoiling anything, about half-way through the game money stops mattering, your upgrades stop mattering and capturing enemies alive doesn't really make a difference anymore. This is a problem as multiple of the player's tools is built around distracting and stunning enemies as well as killing them. The dead or alive element goes out the window, and the game becomes a very generic console fps, complete with parking garage level design. It feels like the game ran short of time or budget and lost everything which made the game unique as a fps.

Overall the game is enjoyable but bland. I would ultimately say that the game is average, but since I can only recommend or not recommend a game, I can't really recommend an average game when there are already so many good to excellent games to play on steam, especially in this genre. For Oddworld fans I would say its worth at least a single playthrough, just so you can have experienced another aspect of the Oddworld universe. As a fan of the first two games on the playstation I was dissapointed that not as much of the same atmosphere was found in this game, although that might be a consequence of the xbox graphics still not being able to provide the same amount of detail as the prerendered environments of Oddysee and Exoddus.

FPS fans can pass on this game, but Oddworld fans should see this game through at least once. That's assuming of course they can get this port to work, since it is infamously unstable. Otherwise skip this port and find it on the original xbox.

reviewText:
Rating: 7/10
Overview: Third/First Person Action Adventure

The Good:

+ The game certainly is original in terms of its character, world and story.

+ Game controls between first and third person and does a great job switching between the two. Third person is mostly used for traversing the environments while first person is used for the crossbow to kill/capture enemies.

+ The premise is simple, but nicely executed. You collect a bounty and then proceed to go hunt it down, usually with a lot of enemies and obstacles along the way. The game is linear and you can only hunt one bounty at a time but each bounty is unique in its own way.

+ Each bounty is unique, like a mini boss battle, each one requires special tactics. You can either kill or capture the enemies. Killing enemies is easier but nets you less money while capturing them is the opposite.

+ Use money to upgrade your character

+ Unique ammo, your crossbow can hold two types of ammo at one time.


The Average:

Graphically the game is decent, it certainly isn't ugly but nothing really stands out.

The story while decent feels like it never meets its potential. It's hard to care about the main character, villains or anybody else.


The Bad

- Broken Achievements, exiting the game makes you lose your achievement progress.

- I really hated the voice acting.

- Game crashes after every death and load in the second half of the game. A reoccurring problem for many users with no fix in sight, making the game almost unplayable. I solution is to quit the game before you die and continue from the main menu.

Conclusion:

For some reason this game reminds of me of a Rare game back in the day. Animals that talk with cute fuzzy ammo to collect. A fun game with some serious technical issues that should be fixed. Given the age of the game its surprisingly holds up pretty decently.

The best console game you never heard of.  Stranger's Wrath was released on the original Xbox, but at a time when other games took most of the attention.  Worse, it was never made backward compatible on the 360.

You don't need to know anything about Oddworld to enjoy this game -- it's not a sequel.  It's a very funny and 'strange' world -- you're in this Old West style country populated mostly by anthropomorphic animal-things (many of which are chickens), and you take bounty hunting missions to capture or kill trouble-causing outlaws.  You use 'live' ammo -- as in, the crossbow actually fires live creatures at enemies, which is really funny.

Halfway through the game there is a MAJOR plot twist / reveal / change, which brings with it a nearly complete switch in gameplay style.  In most games this would be annoying, but this one pulls it off impressively and makes the game very memorable.  There were a couple hard / frustrating bits, but I loved just about every other minute.
Played it when it first came out on the xbox, loved it then, love it now. Would recommend.

Overall this is a great original game thats worth getting. 8/10

I can safely say I haven't played many games that wear as many hats as well as Oddworld: Stranger's Wrath. The gameplay rocks, visuals are strange yet immersive, soundtrack is distinct and has some pretty great pieces, and the story is humorous while still managing to touch on some significant aspects of larger industrial expansion and what it does to the environment. I know that sounds preachy, but it's been a staple of the Oddworld franchise since the beginning, and every game does so just subtly enough to deliver a meaningful message through your struggle as the protagonist.

Anyways, long story short, if you ever wanted a really weird Western, this is the best one you'll ever see. Now go trap some live ammo and hunt some goons!

P.S. Lorne Lanning show us some more Oddworld bby pls.

This is a game that I really wanted to play ever since it came out on consoles. I have just finished the game and I can say that it was fun to play. This review will be broken up into several parts

controls: controls can make or break a game. When I started this game the controls were all over the place. The shoot/punch button was start capturing was R3 and other weird crap. Weather the game didn't detect my 360 controller layout or what I don't know. It took me a good hour to configure everything correctly but after that no issues were had. The controls are a bit stiff but that is a small gripe and I think its due to it being an older title and being a hybrid game. The controls weren't bad by any means but they did get in the way several times. The camera was so so most of the time it cooperated but occasionally it did not. Overall the controls weren't too bad but were a weak point in my experience of the product.

Story: About a 7 out of 10 the story had a lot of personality and spunk although the npcs could get a little annoying and the main character was really bland due to his slow speaking drawl. There was the occasional where do I go or what do I do but by process of elimination or asking npcs you found your way quickly enough. It however did lack any suspense. There's quite a few occasions where you can see whats about to happen an hour or two in advance but it doesn't get in the way too much and the stories entertaining enough to keep you entertained.

Voice/sound: Both are done quite well it might be part of the HD remake but everything sounded crisp and nice. There were however npcs that would repeat things like a broken record and during fire fights or another conversation it could annoy the crap out of you. Almost everyone has a voice in this game and even though they all sound the same and say the same thing except for main story line characters the world seems lively.

Visuals: Being and HD remake I didn't expect too much I never played the original game so I had nothing to compare it to however the game looked nice and played smooth there were no draw distance issues and the characters all seemed well represented. However there are still some blocky textures and areas that look very similar to each other but being a game from the early 2ks you should be expecting that much. Overall with the overhaul the game looks and feels good. I did however have to change my resolution from 1440X900 to 1200X900 the game just seemed too stretched out and the visuals washed  when on my full resolution settings.

Gameplay: The meat and potatoes if the game is not fun to play whats the point right? This game even with some challenging controls happens to be a joy to play. Your character stranger doesn't use guns instead uses a crossbow with “Live Ammo” living animals as his weapons. Each one is unique and each one is useful unlike some games where you will use a weapon or gun once and never touch it again this game makes every ammo useful to some degree. There are ammos that you will prefer to another but other than that the mechanic is very well done. You are a bounty hunter and throughout the better half of the game you collect bounties which are basically you doing boss runs. The game is a bit linear in this manner go for a bounty collect it go for another one repeat. However this is not the full story for this game and the gameplay switches up after you collect the last guy. You can collect your bounties one of two ways dead or alive. Dead nets you less reward but is easier alive nets you more but is harder. Some bosses are almost forcing your hand to collect them dead as they will not go down easily. And speaking of that this game is surprisingly challenging. Even on normal I found myself struggling in some areas. There are clear difficulty spikes during boss battles and in some other areas. However this game can still be beaten no matter which way you play and for the most part (spoiler) it doesn't matter in the end how you bag them I had troves of money left and I bought all of the upgrades too and never needed to buy ammo. The game doesn't change (far as I know) depending on how you play the game. Overall the game is fun to play with very few flaws.

For a game of its age, it's looking pretty sharp with the HD update, leaping forward and distinguishing itself from the generation that saw it born.
Stranger's Wrath although being part of the large population of FPS, it has enough entretaining elements to distinguish itself from the rest. The hability to whimsily switch between 3rd and 1rst person, be it to turn tail and dodge some bullets or close in and knock some teeth or simply exlpore your surroundings, 3rd person forces a change in strategy as well as gameplay. As for 1rst person, it is pretty standard with only a few variations and some elements thrown in, such as in a pseudo-stealth combat (e.i. neutralize-don't-kill, hiding) however stealth as itself is overpowered but really REALLY situational (scripted settled foliage) and could be better, maybe system limitations couldn't handle line-of-sight detecting at the time. However most of the combat is done in 1rst person, even though you can get creative and trace and strategy mixing 1st/3rd person, 1rst person is more reliable.
As for the lore, even though it moves away from the style and tradition of the rest of the oddworld franchise, it still is rich and organic. A deep world to explore and an even deeper foreground as it forms part of the Oddworld universe, most of it deals with the themes of industrialization, explotation of natural resources and native kinship among others.

My only complains are that it has not much replay value unless you really love the world they present (as much as I did, it made me lose the count of my plays), and the inclompete universe as the story has stalled and no new game releases have added something new to said universe since the release of the original XBOX version. Nevertheless on a scale this game has a well deserved 4/5

Although my favorite Oddworld game is Abe's Exoddus, this is a close second. Unlike the previous games which are puzzle/cinematic platformers, this is a cocktail of an FPS, third-person brawler, platformer, and open world game (The open world is nothing large, but its competent). Above all that though, the main selling point of this game is the ammo. In this game you're not pumping lead into some random-♥♥♥ mercenarys, you're planning each move and thinking of fun ways to kill the many outlaws in the game. This is because you have bugs and small creatures for ammo, which can do a ton of things, like distracting enemies with the very annoying chippunk, or wrapping outlaws in webs to keep them on the ground for a easy capture with the bolamite.\n\nThe game also has a fantastic sense of humor, as per usual with the oddworld series, and a lot of boss fights (Although a few are questionably designed). As for story, Its not as complex as the stories in the main quintology, but its still good, and it provides a good amount of lore for people who are interested in it. (Like me)
